importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the incident, October 19, 2025, marks the occurrence of the cargo plane accident at Hong Kong International Airport, a significant event in aviation safety history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The incident occurred early in the morning, around 3:50 a.m. local time, during the aircraft's arrival from Dubai, which is critical for understanding the timeline of the accident and emergency response.

keyTakeAways: A cargo plane operated by ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport and crashed into the sea.
The aircraft, a Boeing plane, broke in two upon impact and collided with an airport security patrol vehicle, killing two occupants.
The four crew members on board were treated for injuries and are confirmed to be safe.
There was no cargo on board, and the aircraft did not signal distress during approach.
The airport suspended operations on the north runway, but other runways remain operational, minimizing disruption to over 1,000 daily flights.
The flight was operated under an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines, which provides cargo capacity to major airlines.
Hong Kong International Airport has a strong safety record, with rare fatal aviation incidents despite being one of the world's busiest airports.
The incident occurred at a time when the airport was operating normally, highlighting the vulnerability of even high-safety infrastructure to rare mechanical or navigational errors.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A cargo plane operated by Turkish cargo carrier ACT Airlines skidded off the runway at Hong Kong International Airport (HKIA) during its arrival from Dubai at approximately 3:50 a.m. on October 19, 2025, breaking in two upon impact. The aircraft struck an airport security patrol vehicle, killing two occupants. The four crew members on board were treated and are confirmed safe, with no cargo on board. The aircraft was not in distress during approach, and there was no request for assistance. The airport suspended operations on the north runway, though other runways remain open, minimizing disruption to daily flights. The flight was assigned an Emirates flight number but wet-leased from ACT Airlines. Despite Hong Kong International Airport’s historically strong safety record, this incident highlights rare but critical risks in aviation operations.
title: Two killed as cargo plane skids off runway into the sea in Hong Kong
